answers.author: Derek Johnson
answers.text:
Stephanie, 
I would be remiss if I didn't point you to our Succession Planning Topic Page on the Knowledge Network:  http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/topics/kn/Topic/252/Succession_Planning#Tab=Overview 
Virtually all of the information and advice that you're seeking about succession planning can be found there. From useful articles highlighting local examples of innovative policies to reports, studies and guidelines on best practices regarding the training and replacement of your aging workforce. You can even try contacting some of the self-identified experts if you have a particular question that isn't addressed in the literature. Before looking anywhere else, I would recommend that you start there.  
Here are a few documents to get you started: 
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/302033/Succession_Planning 
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/302281/2010_ICMA_Strategic_Leadership_and_Governance_Award_Nominee_Succession_Planning 
http://icma.org/en/icma/knowledge_network/documents/kn/Document/2081/The_Myths_and_Realities_of_Succession_Planning 
Good luck with your search! 
Derek Johnson

author: Stephanie Nissen
text: I am working on a project for one of my Masters of Public Administration courses that will focus on succession planning, focusing specifically on the position of city manager. I was wondering if anyone could share any advice, or provide details about city management retirement procedures.  I looking for retirement procedures dealing with city managers who have been with the township/local government for an extended period of time and are leaving a position, for which a replacement would be a very inolved process.  Thank you so much for any help you can provide.
title: Succession Planning
